awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Resilient Gravitronic Communication System
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project addresses the need for the universal availability of communications, especially in places where traditional communication methods are compromised or unavailable.  Global tension, vulnerability of communication satellites, an increase in the frequency of natural disasters, physical barriers, and human space exploration make resilient communications more important than ever. Since matter is practically invisible to gravitational waves (GWs), such waves can transmit information through a planet or turbulent atmosphere without requiring relay satellites. In the coming decade, components of a coherent gravitational wave communication system have the potential to address these challenges and deliver foundational technology for other advanced applications such as ground based orbital cleanup, planet and planetoid matter composition analysis, asteroid deflection, and wireless energy transfer systems to name a few.

This SBIR Phase I project proposes to build upon research that shows dynamic source mass configurations can change the local gravitational field in regimes detectable by current technology. By improving the gravitational field detector’s sensitivity, implementing fine grained control of local changes in the gravitational field, and comprehensively isolating the system from non-gravitational influences, an improved characterization of induced gravitational field changes may be developed. These advances could lead to improved research tools and methods that are a pathway to the development of future system configurations that generate coherent gravitational waves. This research is an essential step toward directly or indirectly transmitting and receiving modulated information by a resilient gravitational communication system.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Thanks to satellite, radio, fiberoptic, WiFi, cellular, microwave, and laser modes of communication, it is easy to take for granted our near real time, highly available access to data, voice, and video communication. But stability of the world stage is more reliant than ever on communication continuity everywhere and being lured into a false sense of its availability is dangerous. Consequently, it is important that communication methods evolve to address the following limitations and vulnerabilities:

  • Intentional Disruption - Jamming (electromagnetic), Relay Satellite (sabotage), Transmission Line (sabotage), Infrastructure Strikes (wartime)
  • Obstruction - Submarine (water, ice), Underground Facilities (earth), Mountainous Operations (terrain), International Communication (distance), Space Colony Operations (astrophysical occlusion)
  • Sensitive Information Interception - Radio Interception, In-wire Tapping
  • Unintentional Disruption - Natural Disaster (infrastructure), Solar Storms (electromagnetic), Electrical Storms (interference)

If a gravitational wave communication system could be developed, it would address these weaknesses by serving as a primary communication mode for obstructions, a mitigating communication mode for disruptions, and an alternative communication mode for sensitive information. This is possible because the physics of gravitational waves make them nearly invisible to matter and electromagnetism. However, gravitational waves are generally impractical for communication because they are weak and difficult to detect. 

To overcome this challenge, Unspace, LLC is developing a novel Waveguide that concentrates kinetically generated gravitational waves to energy levels viable for communication. The impact of this innovation is that the Waveguide produces a concentrated beam of gravitational waves that can be processed by a receiver of practical size (as opposed to multi-acre gravitational wave observatories such as LIGO (Laser Interferometer Gravitational-wave Observatory)). The primary functional benefit of a gravitational wave communication system is that underwater, underground, under ice, rough terrain, and space colony operations would transmit and receive information through matter without relying on extended antennas, wired infrastructure, and/or relay systems (e.g., satellites). Since a gravitational wave communication system is resistant to electromagnetic interference, adversarial jamming, solar storms, and interception, a secondary system benefit is that secure communication continuity would improve resilience of national infrastructure and national defenses.

During NSF Phase I, Unspace, LLC experimentally measured changing gravitational fields caused by changing the kinetic energy of gravitational sources. By experimentally confirming the mathematical models of kinetically induced changes to the gravitational field, Unspace, LLC was able to design a novel gravitational Waveguide that focuses scattered gravitational waves generated kinetically into a concentrated beam capable of supporting a practical gravitational wave communication system. The objectives of the NSF Phase I project were to upgrade its Energetic Gravitational Anomaly Detector (EGAD) experimental setup to improve:

  • Measurement Sensitivity 
  • Accuracy
  • Repeatability

NSF Phase I helped accomplish these objectives by supporting the upgrade of environmental isolation systems, kinetic system controls, and automation systems. The result was improved fidelity of experimental data that enabled Unspace, LLC to remove scientific risk in support of its NSF Phase II application and construction of a Resilient Gravitational Communication System prototype.

As a broader impact, the investigation could lead to methods for deep geophysical surveys, the advancement of General Relativity and Quantum Field Theory relationships, and methods for dynamic gravitational field propulsion systems.
